description: March 9 - As an anti-disinformation measure, state of Johor police in Malaysia have opened six investigation papers in connection with false reports on the Covid-19 infection after police received six reports on the matter between January and March 7 this year. Four of the cases were being investigated under Sections 203 and 505 of the Penal Code and the other two under Section 233 of the Communications and Multimedia Act 1998 (CMA). Sections 203 and 505 of the Penal Code deal with giving false information and statements conducing to public mischief, while Section 233 of the CMA is regarding improper use of network facilities or network service.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: March 16 - The Malaysia Communications and Multimedia Commission (MCMC) has launched an official Telegram channel for the Sebenarnya.my news portal as part of a measure to curb the spread of fake news regarding Covid-19 on social media. Members of the public can join the Telegram channel through https://t.me/sebenarnyamy and receive the latest and most accurate information about Covid-19 verified by authorities such as the Ministry of Health.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

This also includes all public and private universities as well as vocational training centres.

description: Malaysians will be barred from leaving the country and restrictions placed on the entry of all tourists and foreign visitors into Malaysia.

The Ministry of Health would like to advise all devotees and visitors to always practice good personal hygiene, wash hands frequently with soap and water or sanitisers, wear a face mask, and avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth frequently, to reduce the risk of 2019- nCoV infection during during Thaipusam festival (religious festival).
A standard operating procedure is in place to guide authorities who are carrying out disinfection exercises.
A standard operating procedure is in place to guide authorities who are carrying out disinfection exercises.

Disinfection operations would be continued in trains, buses and ferries managed by Prasarana including (train) stations, bus hubs and ferry terminals. The body temperature of the staff on duty, particularly bus captains, auxiliary police personnel and station workers would also be checked before they were allowed to commence work.
Prime Minister Tan Sri Muhyiddin Yassin (pic) has declared that the entire country will be on a movement control order starting from March 18 to 31 to deal with the rise in Covid-19 cases.

Sarawak adds another level of regulation during this movement control order period by telling Sarawakians that they must be indoors from 7pm to 7am beginning Tuesday (March 24). The regulation will last until March 31.
A movement control order in Malaysia was initially from March 18 to 31. However, it has been extended to April 14.

An enhanced order will be imposed in Hulu Langat, Selangor, where 71 out of 274 individuals from a Tahfiz school test were confirmed to be infected with COVID-19. Residents will not be allowed to leave their homes and no visitors will be allowed to enter the area.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 19th, Malaysian police have formed a special task force to identify individuals travelling interstate without permission to celebrate Aidilfitri across the country, says Inspector-General of Police Abdul Hamid Bador.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: In Malaysia, visits to homes are permitted on first day of Raya celebrations only (May 24th). This is a restriction of religious gatherings. Visits, too, would be limited to just family members and are to be capped at a maximum of 20 people for the entire day.
type_text: In Malaysia, visits to homes are permitted on first day of Raya celebrations only (May 24th).
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Malaysia, the police and armed forces will go on patrols during the Hari Raya Aidilfitri celebrations to ensure the conditional movement control order (MCO) standard operating procedures are being followed.
type_text: The police and armed forces will go on patrols during the Hari Raya Aidilfitri celebrations to ensure the conditional movement control order (MCO) standard operating procedures are being followed.

description: Malaysia has agreed to relax the four people per vehicle limit effective tomorrow, Defence Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced today. Policy takes effect on May 27th, and this is a lifting of social distancing restrictions.
type_text: On May 27th, Malaysia will relax the four people per vehicle limit.

description: Malaysia's Unity Ministry today released list of 174 non-Muslim places of worship allowed to resume operations on June 10th, after the movement control order (MCO) is lifted on June 9th. Number of people in attendance at gatherings cannot be more than 30, and only prayer services are permitted. Wedding activities are postponed to July 31st.
type_text: Unity Ministry released list of 174 non-Muslim places of worship allowed to resume operations on June 10th.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Malaysians who have returned from overseas have to go for a health check-up and undergo self-quarantine for 14 days.
Covid-19 patients must test negative twice before being discharged. Isolation
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description: Malaysia will change its Covid-19 treatment protocol and discharge patients after 14 days of quarantine, even if they test positive for the virus. Health Ministry director-general Dr Noor Hisham Abdullah said today that patients' infectivity levels have been found to plunge to zero after two weeks.

Malaysia will change its Covid-19 treatment protocol and discharge patients after 14 days of quarantine, even if they test positive for the virus. Health Ministry director-general Dr Noor Hisham Abdullah said today that patients' infectivity levels have been found to plunge to zero after two weeks.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description: All Malaysians will now be allowed into Sabah without the need to undergo the mandatory two-week quarantine, however, they would have to be certified free Covid-19, with the test done 3 days before their arrival in Sabah from Peninsular Malaysia, Sarawak and Labuan. A letter from the Health Ministry to validate the Covid-19 negative tests should be provided on entry. Malaysians and foreigners working in Sabah would have to produce a valid work pass or other relevant documents.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: The Government will be banning public gatherings of over 250 people in a bid to contain the spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Prime Minister Tan Sri Muhyiddin Yassin said the prohibition of movement and mass assembly nationwide would include all religious, sports, social and cultural activities. Muhyiddin added that all religious activities in mosques and surau will be suspended in line with the Special Muzakarah Council's decision on Sunday (March 15). He said that this includes Friday prayers.

From May 4, Malaysia's economic sectors involving mass gatherings will continue to be closed. Individuals are prohibited from joining group activities and sports involving physical contact such as football, rugby, night clubs, entertainment outlets, swimming at public pools, religious mass gatherings, exhibitions, and Ramadan food bazaars. Activities involving ten individuals or fewer, such as tennis, jogging, cycling, golf, and running will be permitted.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions
